There is actual love and passion in this movie and natural strong performance, you can barely tell that people are acting, all so natural. I'm demolished after this gem and disappointed at the same time that lead Emilia Jones ain't a pro singer, I want to buy her album.... THAT VOICE! OMEGA TALENT! Acting and singing like that... I bend the knee... How come I've never seen her on big screen is beyond me but I hope I will see on screen more of those brilliant cast.Huge Thank You people for that outstanding extraodrinary work and brilliant made movie.
. . . and heartwarming film in a very long time. Stellar performances by all five actors, more especially by Troy Kotsur.Out of the 10 best picture 2022 nominations, my selection is CODA.

Loved this film since it's about a young girl who can talk but uses sign language to communicate with her family but when she wants to move on to singing, her family deals with some issues and she tries to help them but love the ending where they let her go to singing.

Incredible film that truly puts you in the shoes of each character. So humbled by how resilient this family is when they are faced with hardship I can't even imagine. Gripping story that was incredible moving.

reviews.review_title: Most heartwarming film of the year 2021
reviews.content: From writer director Sian Heder who is famous for her Orange is the new black series has brought here a movie so heartwarming and so generous that you as a viewer can't help but adore the movie for it's simplicity and effectiveness of reaching to the common man a topic hardly touched or referenced.CODA stands for child of Deaf Adults and deals with Emilia Jones as Ruby Rossi who is a CODA and deals with the common problems and dilemma faced by a teenager girl in choosing to stand by her family in their day to day problems or pursue her dreams of becoming a singer.It's a fascinating movie from start to finish with some phenomenal performances by everyone involved. Its is definitely going to win some Oscars come tomorrow Night ( in US of course) and rightly so. This movie has been buzzing around since Last year's Sundance Film festival 🎎 where it won and swept all the fans and critics alike.Using real deaf actors in this movie really Bode well for the movie in general and only adds to the genuiness of the film in portraying this sweet and publicly awkward family. It really shows what are the challenges faced by deaf people in general and being CODA is the toughest of it all. You can see and feel the helplessness of the family members without CODA in general public and the consequences they have to suffer in absence of them. But how this family evolves into something more and their dynamics with one another and how it changes throughout the movie makes it one amazing watch and an unforgettable one.The songs used in the movie are so soothing and mesmerizing that it helps you as a viewer to delve deeper into the movie and back the emotional rollercoaster they are on.This movie is part drama, part comedy (not forced I must say) and a part coming of the age story. Saying anything else would be to undermine the story telling and emotions it generates.You will have to see it to believe it!!!VERDICT: 4.5/5PLATFORM: APPLE TV/PRIME VIDEO.
CODA is one family heartfelt film that will show you lessons of acceptance and its true valaue.
Loved this movie, just beautiful, emotional, well acted, well made. We need more quality movies like this, so much garbage out there. No wonder won so many Oscars.

reviews.review_title: May just be the best film I have seen in the last 5 years
reviews.content: What a joyous and enchanting film this is. It's easy to see why Troy Kotsur won an Oscar, much more difficult to understand why Emilia Jones did not. Eugenio Derbez, Marlee Matlin and Daniel Durant are excellent too. A rare occasion also when it feels like the Best Picture Oscar has gone to the best film! A wonderful film centred around the coming of age of Ruby, the only hearing member of a close knit family. A film that deals with the difficulties facing deaf people, and with family, love, hardship, and ultimately how we humans communicate with and care for each other. Music is another key player too, with a great soundtrack and an unforgettable performance of a Joni Mitchell song during which I had something in my eye. Some truly hilarious moments also along the way, not least an uproarious twist on the embarrassment of being caught at it by your parents! With all the current misery in the world for so many people at the moment this film has the potential to raise people's spirits and is a real celebration of the human condition - now go and watch it, you won't be disappointed.

As far as coming of age stories go, 'Coda' is one of the best I've seen in a long time. It certainly has the cliche elements of a story that involves someone finding their identity, but the way the film truly focuses on heartfelt themes like family, love and friendship is the key to the success this film has garnered since it's August release last year.I am writing this at the time of its recent awards success (BAFTA and SAG awards) and the supporting actor winner for Troy Kotsur really was deserved for the uniqueness of his performance. He evokes humour, love and passion throughout the film and all that is made even more incredible due to him being deaf. Emilia Jones as the central character Ruby was equally as good, she will be a fine actress no doubt and her music tutor Mr Villalobos played brilliantly by Eugenio Derbez was a hilarious gem consistently throughout.Likewise, the score by Marius De Vries compliments the film perfectly. The various tracks produce a variety of feelings that elevate your emotions towards the characters. It's exactly what a soundtrack should do and it played a major part in me loving this film as much as a I did.As most films though, it's not perfect. Perhaps it is predictable come the end, but it's narrative is simple and for me it works well. It was slamming any message down your throats, it's a film you can just observe and learn from, as films should make you feel.A really enjoyable film with many memorable moments, I'm so glad to see it doing well in awards season and while it might be a long shot for Best Picture, you just never know.
I love to watch. A film about family and the search for our dreams. Good acting and great history. I think the Oscar fits well in this movie. It's worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: Spoiler: This is an Oscar picture winner
reviews.content: I've seen many movies this year, and I can guarantee that this one will win the Oscar. It is masterpiece with amazing cast. I love the way they speak and made me laugh.
Powerful story with some very moving performances. A MUST see on AppleTV+. Best movie of its genre in years, and definitely a front-runner for best picture and best actor for 2021.
It makes me think of my own potential and what I could've been. I'm deaf in one ear and no one else in my family ever had hearing issues yet I've always wondered about the CODA experience.

Like the movie. It was nice. But no way this is a Best Picture caliber movie at the Oscar's. It's heartwarming, but very much a Lifetime Movie Channel type. Yes, the movies the past two years during the pandemic have been garbage, but this isn't Oscar worthy in any normal year.
Why nobody say that it's a remake of the french The Belier Family (2014)? A cute remake (better songs), but still a remake 😅

reviews.review_title: Starts out sorta run of the mill but then omg wow.
reviews.content: This movie is beautiful!! Plain and simple. Starts out like a usual coming of age story but develops and grows into a heartrending story of love, acceptance and letting go, taking risks and reaching for one's dreams. A great movie to remind us of our shared humanity it these dark times.

Put simply, Apple original film CODA (a remake of 2014 French film La Famille Belier) that stands for Child of Deaf Adults has no right being as charming and effective as it is, as it takes a generic and even predictable story too great heights to present what is surely one of 2021's great feel good films, one that is guaranteed to leave you with a great big smile on your face come the closing credits.A breakout film of 2021's Sundance Film Festival and one that has impressively made its mark across film award ceremonies and best of lists across the globe, director Sian Heder's film is one that never threatens to offer its viewers something that they haven't seen before in one iteration or another but while it may lull you into its story initially, come the films hugely impressive final acts you begin to understand that Heder and her cast have created a special film full of warmth, heart and soul.Following Emilia Jones teenager Ruby, whose mother, father and brother are all deaf, CODA's story arc wont be surprising to anyone that's ever seen a family dramedy or coming of age tale before but Heder's film earns its stripes through a string of impressive acting turns, a whip-smart script and some hugely emotional segments that are sure to make even the hardest of hearts feel a slight stuttering of movement.Front and centre to this tale of Ruby's journey of self-discovery and her place in the wider world outside of being her families lived in interpreter or boat hand is a career making turn from the awards worthy Emilia Jones.Recognizable from films such as High-Rise and Brimstone as well as TV shows such as Utopia and Locke and Key, Jones may not be new to the game of acting but her hard work here learning how to do sign language as well as sing pays off big time in Heder's film and when she's working onscreen alongside Troy Kotsur or Marlee Matlin as her embarrassing parents Frank and Jackie (a scene involving them chatting to what they believe too be her new boyfriend is all time awkward) or a scene-stealing Eugenio Derbez as music teacher Bernardo Villalobos, there's reason to believe that we are witnessing a serious new talent enter into the picture of Hollywood.All in all CODA plays out the way in which you may expect but its little surprises, intricacies and wonderfully realised moments ensure that when you consider what are the stand out feel good movies from the last 12 months, it's highly likely that this very human and very warm film is going to be sitting pretty at the top of that list.Final Say -It doesn't break new ground but CODA's unique family, wonderfully realised delivery and lead work by a memorable Emilia Jones ensures it's top-tier feel good movie making that is likely to live a long and prosperous life into the future.4 loud car radios out of 5.For more reviews check out Jordan and Eddie (The Movie Guys)

Child of Deaf Adults is Sian Heder's latest masterpiece release, starring Marlee Matlin and Emilia Jones.The film is the progressive insight into living in a family that is three-quarters deaf. Emilia Jones plays hearing Ruby who finds the strength to pursue her passion of music, a talent completely contrasting her family's disability. Heder perfects the balance of displaying the household's struggle in benefiting from their fishing business and Ruby's thriving progression under vibrant music teacher Bernardo, whilst also placing emphasis on her integral role to the family.Emilia Jones spent nine months perfecting American-sign language as well as building up the courage to sing in front of an audience, which she had never previously done. She spoke with Total Film Magazine highlighting how her parents were never pushy, and that she hadn't attending singing lessons/school. Oh and she's British, which having watched CODA, you would not have thought. My point is that this young 19-year-old is special, and demonstrates her qualities and intentions with a real gloss in Apple TV's production.The film on the whole is a work of art, one of the rarest forms of cinematography that is designed to make you both laugh and cry. The comedy within is undefeated and is effective in making the picture seem as relatable as possible, an awkward doctor's appointment followed by an even more awkward bedroom scene is the unprecedented eye-covering sequence that we didn't know we needed!Total Film's interview with Emilia Jones delves into the crux of the idea, and the core of its plan was to display reality, not to generalise, or exaggerate, but to have deaf actors play deaf characters and see how a family that may seem disjointed, can still function comfortably, and how the non-hearing, can still enjoy sound in an alternative form.CODA addresses serious philosophical subjects in such a fantastical manner, which helps the name the film as one of the highest ranking releases this year.

reviews.review_title: An Emotional Look At The Struggles & Triumphs Of The Deaf Community
reviews.content: As so often happens, CODA winning Best Picture at the Academy Awards (2022 edition) inspired me to give it a watch when I may not have otherwise. What I found was a film that is incredibly emotional and forthright in exploring deaf communities and families, if a bit caricature-ish at times in that pursuit.For a very basic overview, the movie tells the story of Ruby (Emilia Jones), who is a CODA (or Child of Deaf Adults). While struggling to manage interpreting for a fisherman father (Troy Kotsur), mother (Marlee Matlin), and brother (Daniel Durant) who often resents her place in the family, Ruby discovers a talent and passion for singing. Cultivated by a high school choir teacher (Eugenio Derbez), Ruby must decide whether to pursue music in college or stay in her Massachusetts hometown to continue supporting her family's needs.What ultimately makes CODA a successful endeavor is its honest and open exploration of the deaf community. Kotsur's role particularly stands out here, what with his inability to get a fish-selling business off the ground using signing instead of words. There is also some very interesting resentment-issue material in the brother/sister relationship, as one sibling is deaf and the other hearing. Most of all, the conflict in Ruby-having to choose between pursuing her own dreams and leaving her family to fend for themselves-is palpable throughout.CODA is also a very emotional film, almost certain to have you holding back tears (if not outright shedding them). Certain familiar conversations are imbued with significant emotional depth, and the film's climax-Ruby's audition for a spot at Berklee College of Music-is beautiful.The only thing holding CODA back from a higher ranking for me? I felt some characters were often more caricatures in certain aspects. Ruby's high school music instructor is without a doubt a driving force in the film, but often borders on cliché. The same could be said for Ruby's boyfriend (Ferdia Walsh-Peelo) at times. For such a deep, emotional film, there were just a few too many scenes where I felt like I was watching a teen high school movie (though perhaps this was intentional).Overall, though, I found CODA to be a solid film that made me think about issues related to hearing-impaired individuals and society at large. For the most part, those issues and their emotional portrayals win the day here.

reviews.review_title: A touching, poignant story well told, well enacted
reviews.content: The film chronicles the trauma of a teenaged American schoolgirl who is caught in a deep dilemma torn between her love and support for her deaf family and her personal aspirations of becoming a choir singer. Her deaf parents and a grown up deaf brother are managing a fishing business and she is their constantly available interpreter to communicate to the outside world. The setting is a small American town.Emelia Jones is simply superb as the 17 year old Ruby who is trying to balance her life while meeting the demands from three aspects of her ongoing life. One, her parents need her constantly as an interpreter; two, her music teacher in school who wants her undivided attention for regular choir singing practice and finally her friend Miles ( her duet partner in singing) in school who adores her and wants to be her friend. Director Sian Heder has very sensitively presented the scenes which will no doubt be loved by the audience. The dialogue builds up emotions very naturally as we watch the the different scenes of Ruby with her mom, dad, brother, music teacher, and friend Miles. All these scenes are very heartwarming and touching. There are a few well shot silent scenes as the father unable to hear Ruby's singing watches the audience members appreciateing the performance. The movie shows that parents do care, do make sacrifices and are not selfish as perceived by the children most of the time. Award level performances come from Troy Kotsur and Marlee Matlin as the parents. They deserve all the awards they get.All told this a very sensitively told and enacted story of family relationships. A trivia of interest is that the actors playing parents and brother are deaf in real life. This makes to make this film on a "must watch" category for this reason too.

reviews.review_title: CODA will give you those Good Feeling Emotions
reviews.content: Very Few Movies move you in a way that CODA does. CODA touches your heart because it is more like real life being filmed. I Very Highly Recommend This Movie. It does drag along in a few spots but everything else is spot on.

A movie, you don't expect.Neither deserve. But maybe what you need.A little on lighter side than those grim art house movies. But it is a perfect one irrespective of most classes. I guess, this is the halfway meet for all those who want something to enjoy as well as those who want to feel more.I'm short of words to express, like they are.P.s. There's no universal sign language. All sign languages are different from each other. (Wikipedia)

reviews.review_title: A very well crafted film. Brilliant and full of heart
reviews.content: A beautiful story of a dream coming true. And it is told brilliantly with so much heart. CODA is a perfect example of a simple story being turned into a spectacle. It has so much to say. You can hear it in the music. The words. And feel it in the signs. It expresses so many emotions. I honestly couldn't fault it in any aspect. Just pure heart.

What would you sacrifice for your family? Would you give up on your destiny? Thats what this film challenges us to think about. Ruby, played by Emilia Jones, does a fantastic job at showing us the hardships of choosing between the life you were given and the life you want to make for yourself.First lets discuss the amazing supporting cast. The brother played by Daniel Durant, the mother played by Marlee Martin, and the Farher played by Troy Kotsur. These three blew me away with the emotion they provided throughout the film while only being able to communicate through sign language. The struggles they endure as deaf family really puts things into perspective. No matter how hard they try to live an ordinary life, society can be rough for the hearing impaired. However, they handle these challenges with grace, and thankfully for the audience, with some comedic relief as well.The best part of the film in my opinion is the relationship between Ruby and her teacher, Bernardo, played by Eugenio Derbez. He doesnt take it easy on her and it really teaches her that neither will the world. The way he challenges her sends a great message that you will need to make tough choices for yourself and your overall well being, and then you need to own those decisions whole heartedly.Overall Coda was an incredible film with a whole cast that I wanted to spend more time with once the final credits rolled. I hope it wins the Oscar for Best Picture!

I laughed. I cried. I cheered. I sang along.I got angry. This is an Academy Award Best
Film Of The Year! Emilia should've been nominated. All the emotions.

reviews.review_title: Quality film with a great leading performance
reviews.content: I was very impressed by this film. Gives a great insight into the joys and struggles faced from both sides, that of the young girl and of her deaf family, and the predicament they face about their future's. There's some great humour in the film and also some touching, emotional scenes. It's a beautiful film. I would recommend to all, young and old.

reviews.review_title: Flat out PERFECT FILM! Best Picture
reviews.content: I went into this movie knowing NOTHING about it whatsoever which made it all a surprise. I was blown away by all of it! The story, the actors, the music, the humor and the emotion! I absolutely adore this movie! I'm so happy that it got nominated in the Best Picture category. The female lead should also have been nominated as well as Marlee Matlin.

reviews.review_title: You want to cry like a baby? Watch CODA
reviews.content: The new AppleTV+ movie directed by Sian Heder will surely hit you like a ton of bricks. It's emotional without being manipulative but rather by making us invested in the characters and their lives.Basically the movie follows Ruby Rossi, a teenage child of deaf adults who has to take a huge responsibility in managing her family from a very young age and her coming of age and trying to have an identity of her own.But that doesn't mean the supporting characters aren't fleshed out. They have their own agencies and they feel real which is probably why the movie works so well. The mother (Jackie) is shown to be conflicted about her daughter growing up as she doesn't want her daughter going away from them. The brother (Leo) is insecure as he feels the family favors and assigns more tasks to Ruby even though he is the older brother. He wants people to know that he can shoulder responsibility and take care of the family. Then it brings us to the father (Frank), featuring a magnificent performance from Troy Kotsur. He steals every scene he is in and his relationship with his daughter Ruby is the heart of the film.There have been complaints that the film is standard and predictable and yes this is true. You can predict the plot points from a mile away because these kinds of movies are made a lot. But still the movie works because of hw dedicated and committed the cast and crew are. They believe in the story and characters and this makes the events happening real. We connect to the characters and are prepared to go on the journey with them. The plot points even though they've been covered a million times feels real because there is a feel of authenticity in this movie.And Emilia Jones(who plays ruby). My god!! What a performance. The movie wouldn't work without her giving it all. She has to be authentic in multiple categories. She has to believable in catching fish, in sign language, singing and an American accent. And I haven't even talked about her acting skills because she has to be unbelievably likeable. We have to be prepared to go with her and she has to manage to be interesting for 2 hours and she does it with so much ease.But the things I loved the most about this movie are the emotional beats. Ruby singing to her dad in the back of the truck and then the song at the audition had me bawling my eyes out. Also, it was genuinely funny with Troy Kotsur being absolutely hilarious. And I also think it's one of the very few movies which treats deaf people with kindness and takes them seriously. They are allowed to be full human beings with problems just like everybody else compared to other films where deaf person's only character trait is that he/she is deaf.Overall, a terrific movie with some plot points which don't feel that sincere compared to the rest of the movie. It's one of those movies which I feel like everyone should watch because it makes you feel so much of empathy.

Hey, as far as recent Best Picture winners go, there's been better and worse. I think CODA mostly works, is fairly engaging throughout, looks and sounds nice, and has some very good acting.Its simplicity and pleasantness makes for a nice watch, but maybe one that won't stick with me. I thought something like C'mon C'mon struck a similar tone and was a little better made and more distinctive overall, but oh well- CODA is better than some of the nominees it was up against for sure, but personally I was rooting for Drive My Car.It's nice though- I don't know what more there is to say. It's a very good movie, but not much more. It does almost everything pretty well, and only has a couple of clunky moments here and there, when it comes to characters seeming to forget conflicts very easily, or the odd line of dialogue that's a bit on the nose.Still, it's a hard movie to hate. It's a solid film and a solid Best Picture winner, but it fell a little shy of great for me personally.

Not sure why I put this one off so long but I can now confidently say I understand some of the major stances I've heard on this movie. First, it is basically a Lifetime movie. The story of a high school girl going through life with her deaf family and the interesting situations, the challenges and opportunities that creates. It can be schmaltzy at times, it can feel overly emotional. Secondly... It just works though. Everyone here is just incredible, they all feel like real people, rich characters with complex lives and personalities, prides and faults. I love that they got actual deaf people to play these parts and that they had them played so well. Its a brilliant film for representation, for demystifying the deaf community and showing that they're just people, people with their own rituals, quirks and habits like anyone else, but people. I laughed when the parents asked what a boy's intentions were with their daughter, I bawled my eyes out when the daughter sang for her father and overall just found myself really affected by this film.I don't know that I would say CODA was the best film of the year, but it was certainly one of them. At the very least I'm not mad that it won for best picture.

reviews.review_title: Captivating, Oscar worthy, Delightful and Authentic
reviews.content: I really was expecting a slow haul when I started this film, something I would feel my eyes getting heavy in as I just counted the minutes down to the inevitable faster paced third act. I was seriously wrong. What made me even think about watching it was the premise.Coda follows Ruby, who is the only hearing person in her family and follows her in her pursuit for her dreams in music but with the fear of abandoning her parents. This is a hugely insightful film.TLDR at the bottom.Starting with everything I loved, and there's a lot of it, the writing. By far, the writing stood out the most to me but not that far behind was the performances by all the actors, notably Troy Kotsur as the father, Frank. The writing here is so natural and it flows from scene to scene. The moments will have you feeling a range of emotions from laughter to having you tear up. Each character has their own distinct personality, and you can really empathise and invest yourself in their lives and see their point of view. From the writing, you get a sense of unity between each character, and it has some wonderful moments between each of the family members; and that's just it, there are always moments with the family, whether it be father and daughter, mother and daughter or brother and sister, it was wholesome and really lets each actor shine in their own right.Speaking of the acting, brilliant stuff here. You can really see their pride and struggles from the acting. Considering that majority of the main cast talk using ASL just emphasises how powerful their body language and facial expressions are. Troy Kotsur brings his all to the table and it was his performance that can really make you shed a tear and also make you laugh out loud. Eugenio Derbez also brings the light-heartedness with his character of being a choir teacher to life. Great acting.All of this was fit in to a runtime 1 hour 51 minutes and it did feel a bit slower in the beginning and did feel longer than the actual runtime, but the film manages to ensure that every scene shown is relevant.In terms of the technical aspects, there wasn't anything outstanding, but I wasn't looking for it. There were moments where I thought the cinematography was great: the wide shots of the lake and the framing of said shots, but otherwise I was so invested in the characters and the narrative that all the technical aspects flew past me but I'm sure the cinematography, soundtrack and all other aspects were a contributing factor in the success of this solid film. It is very apparent, that this was a well thought out film with a lot of passion behind it.It was in the third act; however, I felt the film missed a beat in terms of a little character development, but this was a minor gripe and doesn't take away from the film as a whole, but it did linger with me after the credits rolled.Overall, the film was beautifully crafted and has fantastic performances and great writing whilst also being very insightful. It may be a little predictable, but it creates for a light-hearted atmosphere in the times of its unexpected comedy and it will definitely fog up your eyes.P. S. The parallels between Ruby's musical life and her home life were great and the singing was fantastic.P. P. S. This film definitely deserves the awards and nominations it is getting.TLDR: A fantastic film. Watch it.

CODA is one of the best movies of last year and it might be one of the best of the past few years, it got an Oscar nomination that it very well deserved, I haven't seen many films where deaf people are portrayed on screen and CODA did it amazingly.Throughout the runtime it does such a great job of emotionally investing you in the characters and having fun with it, it is a hilarious, heartwarming, and sometimes heartbreaking film about a CODA (child of deaf adults)The acting is fantastic, Emilia Jones was incredible in this movie and her co-stars complemented her fantastically, the story in this movie is moving from the very first frame and the direction is phenomenal.CODA is a beautiful movie, wonderfully acted, impeccably shot.CODA gets an A+

What a great film and deserving of its Oscar win! It's emotionally moving and funny, and it shines a light on a community (deaf and Coda community) that we don't get to see very often in movies. Truly was the movie of the year.
This movie is so special! I can see why it's been cleaning up on the awards circuit. From the tailgate scene on, I was just wrecked! If you don't get all the feels, something is wrong with you.

reviews.review_title: A hilarious movie riddled with likeable characters
reviews.content: I've been meaning to see 'CODA' for a while now, but the Best Picture Oscar nomination was what finally got me around to doing so. I suspected I was going to like this movie. This has been the strongest type of movie for quite a few years now. Teenager/s (usually female but not always) dealing with school, family, love etc. Of course 'CODA' has a twist with the deaf family aspect, and this helped it become one of the best films in recent times in a genre that was already extremely strong.The acting in this movie is superb. Troy Kotsur received a Best Supporting Actor nomination - and deservedly so - but I feel like Marlee Matlin could easily have earned one as well. Both are absolutely terrific. Also Emilia Jones plays a crucial role in this film being as good as it is. She has to be extremely likeable, believable in terms of her sign language and also musically talented. Don't underestimate just how good she was.I've always said the one thing no film can do without is likeable characters and this movie has them in spades. The character of 'Bernardo' played by Eugenio Derbez is a perfect example of this. This is not an easy character to perfect. The hard-ass teacher (with a heart of gold) doesn't just write itself. It has to be carefully crafted to find the perfect balance. They nailed it here.There are some genuinely funny moments in this film. I'm talking laugh out loud funny. And it really does just come from the characters being themselves. It doesn't feel forced.My only gripe with the film would be that sometimes the conflict/drama comes from Ruby's parents doing some pretty unkind things to her. It's not just embarrassment at their situation of being deaf which they can't help, it's embarrassment at them doing brutal things to her that any parents could do to their child if they felt like it. It's a small gripe but it did bother me a little.Otherwise though I had a very good time with 'CODA'. I'm glad this is getting the recognition it deserves and hopefully it helps to continue this genre of film churning out quality products in the future. 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Perfectly Executed - I adore this movie
reviews.content: A beautiful, intimate film about chasing your dreams.I saw this film when it first appeared on Apple TV and remember saying to myself I needed to watch it but never got round to it. The night after the Oscars, I grabbed a bottle of wine and put this film on more out of interest as to what made this a 'Best Picture' and oh wow did I go into this underprepared.To piece a deaf family with a CODA who has a passion for singing is a great story premise and is fascinating to see play out in front of you.It has been 3 weeks since experiencing this movie for the first time & I still get chocked up thinking about the final 20 minutes of this film. You really empathise with all the characters in this movie and the ending culminates into some of the best cinema I have seen in a long time, not for the wow factor of it but just the subtle nod to THIS is what the film has been building up to and it was executed perfectly.Each actor aces their performances and I would happily watch this film again & again. We need more films like this, 10/10 best film of 2021 hands down.

reviews.review_title: The best film of 2021, no doubt, if the Academy has the guts to go there
reviews.content: Seriously: You will cry and laugh in the first 10 minutes, and the rest of the film will not let go of your emotions. This is why art exists: to tell the stories of human existence-ALL HUMANS. Not just pretty ones (although it is amusing to see the filmmakers try to make Emilia Jones look plain ... they fail hard) or the smart ones ... but the common ones "hiding" in plain sight every day. Human existence, from the ground up, so to speak; not just the stories of great people doing amazing things. The coming-of-age story has been told endless times, and that's good, because there are endless examples of the different ways we all come of age, but this film is so powerful and unique, you will never forget it. Ever.

reviews.review_title: A Remake of a French Film, and Glee Had Better Musical Numbers
reviews.content: Best Movie of the Year? This just shows you that no one should pay attention to the Academy Awards as they have no clue about movies, but then again, there were a lot of terrible movies in 2021.This movie was sweet, but predictable as can be. The French version is sweeter and better if you are looking for something to watch. I just can't get over that they gave the best picture award to a film that was almost a frame-by-frame copy of another movie in another language.Eugenio Derbez was awesome as the music teacher, but he was riffing off the original version, too, as that film had a great character to follow. Derbez is a great comedic actor and proves it in this movie.I'm not sure, but I'm almost positive that you can't start singing during your last year of high school and then win a scholarship to Berklee College of Music, and certainly not by doing just an OK rendition of Both Side Now, but in Hollywood, anything is possible. Pretty weak singing numbers, and as I said, Glee did it better.

reviews.review_title: Sweet, heartwarming and charmingly delightful flick.
reviews.content: One hour into the movie, I felt this is fine and not going in the direction I expected but exactly from 1HR 17minutes, it changed its course and went bonkers with roller-coaster of emotions till the end by giving beautiful , heart tugging scenes one after other and even made my eyes moist. Doesn't mean that first hour is bad, it is quite good and held well by the leads through their outstanding performances , just that it is not on par with the third act. Kudos to Sian Heder , she handled the subject with élan and brought the best emotions from the real deaf guys , hats off.Emilia Jones as Ruby is brilliant, beautiful and incredible throughout. She carried the movie and of course, got amazing support from reel family who did an outstanding job in elevating the movie with their sign act. You eventually become a part of their family, such is the atmosphere and vibe they give through their performances. All the three actors in the movie are real deaf persons and trust me, they make you feel their struggle, plight , emotions just with the signs BRAVO.Troy Kotsur as Ruby's dad is natural and phenomenal. There is one scene in the third act, where he asks his daughter to sing for him and place his hand on her neck to feel it is one of the finest and strikingly beautiful scenes ever. Same goes with the scene where Ruby asks her mother " did you ever wish I was born deaf ? " and the following scene with sign language and no background music made me feel something which is unexplainable. I give credit to actors for making me go through this, love you guys.Had it carried the same third act feel in the first hour, overall rating would have been higher. Yet, it deserves 8 for the actors especially real deaf persons act and for Sian's heartwarming stroke. Couple of issues but forgivable , as it managed to overcome in the final showdown. Do yourself a favor and watch it!!

Of all the awards contenders of 2021, CODA is the feel-good movie of the pack, alongside King Richard. You know exactly where it's going and it goes there, but that doesn't stop it from being a very good and enjoyable movie. There isn't really that much to say about it. It's a movie where the credits roll and you feel uplifted. The premise is that Ruby, a CODA (child of deaf adults) is torn between staying with her deaf family and going off to music school.The movie's best aspect is its acting, especially from Emilia Jones and Troy Kotsur. Of course, it's easy to admire the deaf actor's excellent performances, but those who had to learn American Sign Language for the movie also deserve respect. Even for those of us that don't understand ASL, it still conveys itself as well as the spoken dialogue does. Emilia Jones speaks well, sings well, and does ASL well. It's an all-around excellent performance from her. The screenplay is very good as well. CODA may be feel-good, but it's no sappy Hallmark movie. The weight of Ruby's decision is there, and the effects of either option are worth considering. There is a real emotional weight in the movie, and the relationship between Ruby and her family is very well handled. It also has a very lovely setting in an idyllic fishing village in Massachusetts, featuring some beautiful maritime scenery.While it is a solid film, there are a few things it does wrong. The relationship between Ruby and Miles, her school classmate/crush, goes back and forth without much to build it up or make it meaningful. There is also too much sexual humor in the movie. While I do understand that they wanted to show that deaf people can be sexually active, there's too much of it in other places. The part with the choir singing a decidedly dirty song in school felt kind of icky. These are mostly minor issues, though. CODA is a solid film boosted by excellent performances and a great screenplay. But above all, it's a uplifting movie. Sometimes that's just what you need. Serious dramas have their place, but sometimes you just need a film like this to lift your spirits.

A moving picture which managed to capture heart and soul as well as the complexity of relationships quite eloquently, Sian Heder's CODA is a well deserved best picture win. The shining performances from Troy Kotsur and Emilia Jones sweep the floor, portraying a what seems to be a troubled, yet energetic, and live family, CODA is without a doubt a movie you should immerse yourselves into.

reviews.review_title: Love cannot be stopped by disability.
reviews.content: Ruby Rossi is the only hearing person in her deaf family. As the only "normal" person, she has to be a baller in taking up responsibilities to protect her family in all ways she can, even though she is the youngest. However, as adolescence approaches, a period when one begins to have his/her own dreams, fantasies and love pursuits, Ruby has to make difficult choices of either being true to herself or loyal to her family. This sounds like a very hard decision to make. Yet, with an understanding and supportive family, where communication goes way beyond words, there is always a way out which does nothing but only strengthens the familial bond.CODA is a beautiful and touching story. Many of the scenes are the Rossi family communicating in sign language. But you don't feel a gap or any problems of understanding what they are conveying. No doubt this is all about the impeccable writing and acting.In the movie, you can feel how hard the Rossi family find it to fit in the community. How hard it is to make ends meet when the fishing business is going downhill. And the fear that they would fail, as a parent and as a child. But with sincere and genuine conversations, the Rossis talk ( in sign language), they listen and they choose love. Quite a lot of touching conversations in the movie that you have to watch for yourself. I can't help but broke into tears as we all know this is not easy to come by in real life. And it is chilling to feel this genuine kind of love in the big screen once in a while.In the midst of pandemic, I would strongly suggest you watch this movie to remind you that there is still something worth fighting for.

This movie make me think about how lucky I'm to being born with the full advantage to life, and we are not appreciate it enoughAlso the story is very much reality nothing cinematic really and and the acting is on point and you can see how hard the actor working on itThe movie simple and have meaning like our life should be.

reviews.review_title: I cried to see this movie with a good song atmosphere
reviews.content: As CODA (Child of Deaf Adults), Ruby is a deaf teenager who is able to hear among her deaf family members helping her family run smoothly in the midst of her dream of becoming a singer.CODA is an English film adaptation of the French-Belgian film of the same name. CODA has a story full of life meaning and full of moving emotions. The plot of a family drama is dense and not wasted in building the story and characters. Presenting a family drama with a different atmosphere, the existence of a deaf family with her daughter who is able to hear. A family drama that is so complex and complicated. A good conflict throughout the film with a lot of pressure experienced by Ruby. The presence of conflicts that come in a barrage in each scene. The conflict is built to perfection, with the slow pace of the film to make room in providing such a moving atmosphere.The film almost uses sign language in dialogue. It's become a new experience and a new learning in trying to understand sign language and deaf friends. However, this film has good dialogue, is not boring, able to present its emotional and entertaining feel in the comedy side. Good acting from deaf actors in playing deaf roles. The emotions obtained can still be felt and look much more passionate.

Wow! Every second of this movie is just full of love. Watching the family members interacting with each other, living their moments toghether just made me cry and lauch at the same time each 3 minutes. This one should get the oscars this year, for sure. Amazing!

I knew nothing about this movie until the nominations were announced. What a pleasant surprise! The lead performance by Emilia Jones was.perfection. I was shocked when I learned she was English. All the performances were great, especially Troy Kotsur, Marlee Marlin and Daniel Durant, who all happen to be deaf in real life. Movies don't usually get me all emotional, but the scene on the truck between Ruby and her father, and the scene with Both Sides Now brought tears to my eyes. I loved this movie from start to finish and have already watched it twice.

Personally not into this kind of musical theme movie but this one is an exception. I like the way how the family with disability can make a brilliant life even more than ability persons. Life is not meant to be lack of something will turn you down but it could be full of hopes and happiness.

reviews.review_title: Coda offers a new perspective and shines in it
reviews.content: Coda is definitely one of those films that you want to keep coming back to. Its heartwarming, hilarious and wholesome. It has a small cast that absolutely smash it, especially the three actors that are deaf.Coda innovates. It's a different coming-of-age story, one that offers a fresh perspective. Coda means "Child of Deaf Adult". Ruby is a member of a deaf family, in which only she is not deaf. She loves to sing but her family can't here her. And challenges rise from there.One of the best things about Coda is that it never stops giving, every moment in the film is delivered perfectly. The emotions hit you in the right spot, the drama is intense and the comedy sticks the landing. Like the clever use of sign language to converse with someone who is not learned in ASL but gets what that person is trying to convey given the circumstances. Or showing the shortcomings of being deaf while simultaneously not making them seem less able than others. It perfectly shows you what it feels like to be a deaf person.It is perfectly easy to understand sign language via subtitles but the way those actors deliver those signs makes it even more emotional than normal speaking lines.Emilia Jones plays a fantastic role as Ruby. Ruby's story, although unique, is very relatable. I like how the film doesn't over-focus on school stuff and teen romance like some other films. This gave time for and space for Emilia to show her great talents as an actress.Overall, Coda is definitely one of the best films of 2021 and I 100% recommend watching this.

reviews.review_title: Overlook the clichés and it's beautiful
reviews.content: This film made me happy. It's like a warm hopeful hug that I think people need right now.CODA brought many things to the table. Hiring real deaf actors truly brought authenticity to this film. The subtle moments we take for granted was encapsulated so well. It makes you realise you have it pretty good. You can clearly see the level of careful research Siân Heder took.I've never seen Emilia Jones in anything else (apart from "One Day" lol) but she was fantastic. I love films this way since she was a blank page that she started to paint. She took responsibility of this role and delivered to great effect.I thought some story beats, acting and locations were very formulaic, even cliché. It became fairly predictable which made me lose the story a bit. You've seen this story a good amount of times but it still felt fresh.The cinematography was nice but I wish there was something else to it. It was very clean with sharp lenses making it feel very digital. Unless they wanted that look, I feel it could've perhaps lended itself to some imperfections in the image like using filmstock or vintage lenses. I feel it would fit the story really well but perhaps that's just my own taste.This film has great beautiful moments that I'll remember. Some of the clichés can definitely be looked past, because some scenes (especially in the third act) were beautiful. A clash of love, perspective and meaning, CODA brought it all. Fun to see films like this get awards praise.
This is all about the script . Add to that good acting, directing and a good mixture of seriousness and comedy. This is how a low budget film conquers.

Saying I loved this film is an absolute understatement. I think it's one that everyone should see in their lifetime. Emilia Jones is an absolute STAR in this, along with the rest of the talented cast. Don't be surprised if you shed a few tears watching...

Beatiful Remake of the french film "La famille Bélier", has a great cinematography, a very nice score and soundtrack and it sticks in your head for a long time after seeing it. Definitely worth the time.

RATED 9/10
Language: English
RECOMMENDEDSuperb family drama with high values in everything. The cast is ultimate and superb screenplay. The sign language is handled excellently... The family values and their struggles are portrayed in very interesting way. Must watch.
Wasn't sure what to expect but my god what a wonderful movie! Heartwarming and beautiful, cried my eyes out. Loved it and one of the best movies I've seen in a long time.

reviews.review_title: its a perfect movie about family and life love it!! and enjoyed it
reviews.content: Its a perfect movie about family and life love it!! And enjoyed it! Wonderful movie very simple yet very nice and enjoyable, very funny as well.. you will, be entertained...

reviews.review_title: A Deeply emotional movie about deaf people
reviews.content: I just watched the movie. Although I didn't know non of the actors and actresses, but The performances were incredible. I loved the relationship between Ruby and her family. In my opinion, the movie had two most significant sequences. First, the scene which Ruby's family attended in a salon to watch Ruby and suddenly we were faced with a silent sequence, it was wonderful. Second, the sequence which the father as a deaf person struck his daughter's neck to deeply sense her singing. I was emotionally affected. All in all, it was the best film that I've seen in the last two years.

I was very moved by the ending rendition of 'Both Sides Now'. I didn't expect to be moved as much as that! It was very emotional.The strange thing about CODA is how low budget it feels in places. The acting isn't that fantastic either and their are no recognisable faces (to me) in it. Also, the deaf parts of 'dialogue' in which I understood absolutely nothing were quite drawn out and require your own personal interpretation. So, why did I feel so emotional at the end? I really have no idea.I guess CODA is filmed in a very unassuming and unpretentious manner with little or no ego or selfishness, which is reflected in the low-key unity of the family to just get on with it, no matter what.Or maybe I'm just a sucker for Joni Mitchell music and happy ever after soppy(ish) movies, but for whatever reason, I really enjoyed this presentation and was moved by the simplicity of it all, and perhaps the gaps in dialogue and non-intelligible sign language had a subconscious effect on my brain.I liked CODA a lot.

"Love is deaf. You cant just tell someone you love them. You have to show it." CODA (Child of Deaf Adults) is a fitting tribute to this adage & epitomizes hope and kindness with utter pure heart and soul.As you start watching, being a silent film for majority of its part, it makes you anxious about the fact that there are going to be no subtitles or dialogues to help you navigate here. But pretty soon as you go deeper into the sea of emotions, you are struck by the presence of the most powerful language in the world. Love.Sprinkle it with a sumptuous mix of soothing music and all you are left with is an experience worth remembering. A heart warming glimpse into two different worlds separated by sound but connected with love.CODA is easily one of the best films of the year so far. A great blend of ambition and sacrifice, it makes you believe that there is always light at the end of the tunnel. All you need to do is to stop cribbing and channelize your energy in the right direction.

One of the most beautiful movies i have ever seen.The plot is predicted but yet so beautiful.You cry and laugh at the same time, and this is the way life is, so that's why it so authentic.Passion made this movie happen. Also, the fact that those are deaf actors, makes it more real and more beautiful. This is a movie I love and respect.Those movies reminds me of why love the art of filmmaking.

4 out of 5 stars.Great story about a teen girl living with a deaf family which they rely on her to be there intrepreter. They want her to stick with the family fishing business. While she is wanting to follow her dreams in singing.It is sad. Cute. And charming in every way. Great acting. And a strong story about a family and her trying to grow as individuals.

Maybe the movie it's not as good as I think it is, maybe it just caught me at the right moment but it had a big impression on me. I really loved it and it sparked in me a desire to do more, to connect to people, and especially to help people. I really hope that I'll follow with action on this feeling.

The prepreparations for the Oscar's continues. And it's time for CODA. A movie that i've been having on my watchlist for a very long time.CODA is a movie about Ruby, the only hearing person in her deaf family. And she is torn betweeen pursuing her love for music and fear of leaving her parents.I had really high hopes for CODA. I have heard so much good things about this movie, and it meet all my expectations. It is sad, cute and charming in every way. The acting is great and it has a strong story about ruby and her family, and how they are trying to grow as individuals.I can really see why this movie is nominated in the best picture category. And i wouldn't be suprised if it wins, maybe it even deserves to win.

reviews.review_title: A feast for the eyes and the ear!
reviews.content: This film really warms the heart. Its about following your dreams and looking back at those who have your back. Family love still gives the best support for you to reach the stars. Even though others think of them as incapable you realize that they have done much more than others.

reviews.review_title: Watch It, There Is Nothing Else To Tell You
reviews.content: Plot: even if at the beginning it's a bit predictable and seems pretty simple, the more you get through it, the more it deserves. And the more it makes you think "Better to know someone before judge and badmouth him/her".Actress, Actors and Acting: well, Emilia Jones, the main character, did a breathtaking performance. Her family did an extremely good work too, really. Well done, everyone, I hope to see you in other movies!Soundtrack: good, in particular it was extremely well managed. Once you have watched it, you'll get it.Conclusions: a movie that everyone should watch and think about it, about the depicted situation and not only.Watch, enjoy, sob if needed, and then think.

reviews.review_title: Something we wanted to see in a long time.
reviews.content: This movie is just beautifully done. I am out of words for this masterpiece. The amount of struggle disabled goes through and the trouble there loved ones have to tackle is enormous. This movie shows it wonderfully. Not boring at all and has all the elements a perfect should have. I loved it you might like it too.

"Tears and fears and feeling proud
To say 'I love you' right out loud
Dreams and schemes and circus crowds
I've looked at life that way."CODA is the most awarded movie in Sundance history. It deserves a few Globe and Oscar nods, too. UPDATE: it won 3 Oscars - Best Picture, Best Actor and Best Adapted Screenplay.Emilia Jones has arrived. She is no longer just a teen actor. And she succeeds in making her character sparkle like the bright star her father in the story was missing in the Massachusetts night sky.About those who criticize CODA as a ripoff of La Famille Bélier as if it's some clandestine plot: CODA acknowledges it *in the credits*! At timestamp 1:48:20: " Based on the original motion picture 'La Famille Bélier'
a film by Eric Lartigau written by Victoria Bedos, Stanislas Carré de Malberg, Eric Lartigau and Thomas Bidegain."
I am sooooo happy this movie won the Best Picture Oscar!!It has everything: humor, joy, sadness, and every emotion in between. Bravo to Apple TV for bringing this magnificent movie to us!

reviews.review_title: Amelia Jones Best Actress in an Outstanding Cast
reviews.content: This is a very powerful dramatic film where the common place is profound. Amelia, Ruby, is the pivotal character because she is the misfit. I say that with love and respect, because it is her unique position in the family juxtaposed to their unique position in the community that creates the dynamic tension. She is so skilled in her role that you believe her without hesitation while her film family is believable because they are, in fact, deaf. Together they bring you into their world where we experience our common humanity in their exceptional circumstances. There is a wonderful blend of drama and emotion that had us crying with tears of joy throughout the film.

This movie is extremely good, from every point of view. The problems that the girl has can be extrapolated and seen on a day-to-day basis in real life. It is excellent when they film the movie from the point of view of deaf people, then the ending with the girl singing is a work of art.

What a special unique film full of perfectly measured acting and touching moments. Simple in concept but rich with the depth of so much more. Some truly touching moments so well framed and acted it earned many of my tears. Best moment: *spoiler* when the daughter sings to her deaf father and he experiences it by touching her vocal chords. Wow. Also great was the moment when all is silent during the concert and we experience what her family does. Also had the effect of reminding me how blessed I am to be able to hear the beauty that is music and to never take that for granted. One tiny point off from me - again *spoiler*: it is preposterous that the professional accompanist could not accompany Ruby's choice of a Joni Mitchell classic. But it worked for the touching moment that followed so I'll forgive it.
Just ignore the low score ratings these are by people who like to try to appear clever but are really just not. Great film great perfomance by all,feel good movie,just sit back relax and enjoy.

Beautiful movie, I really want to watch the original, "The Bélier Family", so beautiful and painful, the family's dialogues are beautiful, fun and dirty, the sexual approach and professional independence of this family is cool, and, at the same time, the dependence on the only listening member, and this dilemma causes immense pain to us as mere spectators... An exciting film...

If this film does not win on awards then people in this world have lost their way. This is truly a heartfelt and emotional movie. You cannot help to be pulled into this families story. Great cast, wonderfully done!!!Loved seeing Marlee Matlin again in a movie too! I always enjoyed her acting.
This was a touching film with great acting. Every scene conveyed deep emotions. The coming of age story was upgraded with this tight family bond.

Like The Belier Family, CODA is about a female teenage with deaf parents and an older brother. She is torn between her passion and dream for singing, and being an essential interpreter for her family (that is needed for the daily operations of the fishing business). Both movies are not like any other coming-of-age movies. This movie puts a spotlight on the deaf community, and also, the deaf characters are played by deaf actors. With that, the tender family warmth is portrayed in the dymanics of the characters, between hearing child and deaf family members. All in all, beautiful narrative, beautiful cast and beautiful singing.

This movie reflects our life and problems, in some scenes they makes me cry and in others makes laugh, but it was such great movie .........................................................................................

This is a 6 tops, more like a 5. Definitely not a 8. Very average story and acting. So many clichés. I guess the fact that it's an Amazon Prime movie must have influenced its rating on IMBD, since it's all the same company. The best thing about this movie is the representation and visibility it brings to the deaf community. Actually it's pretty much the only good thing. The rest is very meh.

I can't remember last time i was this much invested in a movie.CODA is a simple story, elevated to highest of heights with a good storytelling, emotional core, beautiful performances, and really important subject in its center.I want to especially praise Emilia Jones, who is up and coming superstar for sure, and Troy Kotsur, who gave one of the rawest and most believable performances that i saw recently. Also, above all, i want to praise brilliant chemistry between these 2 actors, because i was totally doubting, while i was watching the movie, that they might actually be real life father-daughter.I'm a little bit confused why is there no comedy genre tag, neither here nor on IMDB, because this movie has plenty of comedy moments, and all of the jokes land.Now, i was thinking to myself: ''Yeah, i enjoyed this movie so much, but should i really give it 5/5 stars, because at the end of the day it's nothing groundbreaking or innovational?'' And the answer is, as you saw already, ABSOLUTELY YES!CODA is touching and heartfelt drama about life struggles of a family. Not your ordinary family, but still a normal family, and a daughter at the center of it. It knows what it is, and it tells that story. It doesn't need to be anything else, and it is amazing at what it is.

Somehow, i came across that movie.and i was hooked from the beginning. The fishing family which is a deaf apart from the daughter is trying to make some money in the small city. The deaf parents use their daughter as a translator. As it turns out the girt has a huge gift.in the form of her voice. The movie shows her path throughout.the live.

reviews.review_title: The New 'Star Is Born' meets a metaphorical coming-of-age story. So many metaphors and feelings and they don't need words at all.
reviews.content:
CODA (2021) :
Brief Review -The New 'Star Is Born' meets a metaphorical coming-of-age story. So many metaphors and feelings and they don't need words at all. Yes, even today's modern stories can be metaphorical. Here's the proof. Not a regular coming of age story but a film with right emotions and sensitive conflicts. The reason to call 'The New Star Is Born' is nothing logical. It just 'came out'. It took me back to those days when musicals had heart at the right place unlike today's mediocre works that are being loved undeservingly. As a CODA (Child of Deaf Adults) Ruby is the only hearing person in her deaf family. When the family's fishing business is threatened, Ruby finds herself torn between pursuing her love of music by wanting to go to Berklee College of Music and her fear of abandoning her parents. So many metaphors in such a short time, I wonder how they managed it. This film is full of metaphors, you just have to keep your eyes and brain open for that, and yes more than ears. The girl is screwed up, not even that, I felt like she's tossed up in the air and is unable to decide which side to fall on. The mother confesses that she wished that her daughter should be deaf like her so that they won't have differences. The father, he's such a freak, such a blast of a person but does understand the right thing. The brother, though damn regular, is quite a sensible man who wishes his sister to go away- only for her best. The entire family is so freaking hilarious, vulgarly funny, sometimes messy but as a whole- a lovable affair. That last scene when the girl tells her mom, let's not make this a thing and then she herself comes back to make a scene. You know what, that's how a family should be. I found so many metaphors throughout the film but i think it missed that in the climax. Though it was sensible and realistic, I think it could have been better. Overall, a nice break from regular musicals and family dramas and please find your different metaphors on your own.RATING - 7/10*By - #samthebestest.

WOW! This is such a moving film. There is so much to like about this movie. I followed Emilia Jones filmography to this after seeing her excellent work in LOCKE AND KEY and was pleased to see that Academy Award winning actress Marlee Marlin was also attached to this project. This movie is not just about being a CODA (Child of Deaf Adults) it is about a family in crisis, coming of age, finding yourself, following a crush but realizing a totally different passion, being unique, and somewhat isolated, in a larger community, struggling for a fair livelihood, making sacrifices and holding a dream. This film won four of the major awards at Sundance plus awards from 8 other media festivals/entities. I give this film a 9 (superb) out of 10. {Drama, Music and Romance} and, in case you are curious, as I was, the final sign in the movie is a modified familial sign for I LOVE YOU (ordinarily the first two fingers are not crossed in this sign).

reviews.review_title: Sing like no one is listening.
reviews.content: Emilia Jones as Ruby Rossi, a musically talented 'child of deaf adults' (C. O. D. A.). She should have got Best Actress. This wasn't just acting but a touchingly real struggle to follow her real life father, the famous tenor singer, Aled Jones*. Emilia has a vibrant voice that is sweet as dolce vino.Although a poor fishing family, the Rossis are rich in love and togetherness. Don't laugh now at deaf people, for they can't hear you scream when they beat you up. Troy Kotsur tells dirty jokes in sign language, in lol hand gestures (and screen subtitles). Having deaf parents means that they'd be quarrelling in silence and Ruby (Emilia) could escape and play her radio music on at full blast, loud enough to wake up the whole neighbourhood, without waking up her deaf 'parents'.They say 'sing like no one is listening'. Her family's literally tone deaf and only her singing teacher hears her talent. But if she wins that music scholarship, the world will soon be listening. Teenage discovery movie, discovery of music and love and sacrifice. The love parents have for their child. "Tears and fears and feeling proud, to say "I love you" right out loud".* Emilia sings naturally, inherited vocals.

reviews.review_title: The Best Drama Movie So Far in 2021
reviews.content: This movie comes with heartwarming, merriment, uneasy feelings, and teenage dream.I've just finished watching this movie and I'm still basking in the afterglow of the movie.I'm ashamed that I didn't know what CODA is until I watched this movie. So I looked it up in the dictionary.While I was watching this movie I really felt her complicated feeling that she wants to go her way but feeling guilty left her family behind.She was the only one to hear in her family, and she found what she really wants to do which was singing songs and go to music college.Thanks to her music teacher and her boyfriend's support, helped her to go on.After watching this movie, I got to know that her parents are both deaf, and that way the acting was so real and persuasive.I love the last scene that she sang a song with sign language on an audition for family.The moment was really heartwarming and I felt a family connection.I highly recommended this movie.

I have not seen a movie like 'CODA' yet. The movie is about life in / with a deaf-mute family. 'CODA' manages to realize the entire story with an immense authenticity, dramaturgy and kindness.The movie consistently relies on sign language again and again and leaves the viewer alone with it. It is fascinating what effect facial expressions and gestures alone can have. Through sign language, you don't understand what exactly is being discussed, but you do understand in which direction a dialogue is developing, which feelings are being triggered and what the context is.The frame story is basically run-of-the-mill, but that's not the point here. It's more about the interpersonal relationships and the tensions within the family. In addition, it is impressively shown what it means to be deaf and with what difficulties one is confronted.The acting performance of Emilia Jones also deserves special mention. She was really good and I found it impressive how authentic her use of sign language was. I totally bought her role.It's really refreshing that there are movies like 'CODA'. Movies that break the conventional mainstream pattern and dare to go other ways. Of course, you have to get involved with the movie and be in the right mood. But it's worth it.

Such a great film it is. Sian Heder managed to balance everything perfectly, I loved the sense of humour which were present all over the film.It was a perfect choice to use actors and an actress from the deaf community to play the parts. It was absolutely amazing to see them in real life actions like normal deaf people who have sexual desires and joke around. They're not two dimensional like they had been depicted in other films before here.Troy Kotsur was remarkable and must won an Oscar for his parts. Actually everyone was great.It's an emotional film that touches you from lots of different aspects.The most emotional scene was the one when the father was trying to feel the vibration of her daughter's voice through her throat and feel the thing that she's feeling. Actually I couldn't control myself there...I think it should win the Best Picture at the Academy Awards.Its screenplay was remarkable and must win an Oscar for sure. For Best Adapted Screenplay category because it wasn't an original one.It was actually an English-language remake of the 2014 French film La Famille Bélier.8.3/10.
An immensely beautiful film that takes us on a journey of introspection. Its all about what really matters in life. Embrance it with open arms. In my top 10 without any doubt!

reviews.review_title: A Wonderful Story About Being Hearing in a Deaf Family
reviews.content: It's ironic that I'm speechless after seeing CODA. It has everything a phenomenal movie should have and more.As a 30+ year nationally-certified interpreter at the master level, I was hesitant to see CODA when I heard through the Deaf grapevine that the actress who played the daughter of Deaf adults wasn't a Child Of Deaf Adults, nor knew sign language previously. However, for a Deaf movie which includes music as an integral storyline, I understand the decision for the choice to choose an actress outside of the Deaf community.I've seen thousands of movies - most of my ratings of each on IMDB. I haven't changed my top ten movies in years, but CODA is the exception. Coda is a must-see movie for everyone.

reviews.review_title: I tried to resist...but CODA wore me down.
reviews.content: CODA is a baby harp seal of a movie. And though I have issues with the formulaic nature of its plot and the lack of surprise (except for how emotional I got at the end) I am putting down my critic's club and focusing on all that's great about this sweetest film of the year.I'm a cynic with a heart of mush. All it takes to successfully manipulate me into a vulnerable state are good intentions mixed with truth; unexpected kindness; valiancy and the possibility of redemption. Great acting also helps. And a beautiful girl with a beautiful voice singing a Joni Mitchell classic. (If for no other reason than that it sends a bunch of young folks on a journey to discover our greatest living songwriter, CODA deserves its position on Oscar's Best Picture list).Plus, I love a movie that shows people over fifty being sexually active. Even when (as here) it's primarily played for laughs. Marlee Marlin and Troy Kotsur make for a sexy, goofy couple. And I didn't mind their mutual carnality, even when engaging in some afternoon delight that can be heard through the walls of their bedroom, much to the horror of their 'at the end of her rope' daughter Ruby, (a sweet-natured Emilia Jones).The story of conflict between artistic pursuit and familial responsibility is well trod. But the fact that Ruby is the only hearing member of her family - and that she is a singer (therefore her art will never be enjoyed fully by the people she most wants to share it with) - lifts CODA from the mundane and sends it into a kind of metaphoric Valhalla. And though I may have seen the ending coming from a mile away, I sure didn't see how strongly I would be effected by it.Sometimes Bennett falls asleep on my arm and drools all over my hand- Sometimes when I'm smooching his tummy I get overwhelmed and cry all over his fur. It's good to feel things. This movie is an unapologetic weeper. I have no shame for shutting down my critical eye and being utterly ensnared.
I was totally blown away by this incredible movie. The cast was amazing and I loved every minute of it. This movie should be on the everyone's must see list.

This was a very moving, fun and at times sad movie that really made you care about the characters, their work and their life. I thought it did have the right balance where it didn't get too serious or slow but at same time didn't get too sappy or melodramatic. The main girl did a great job showing so many emotions and was a very powerful performance. One of the best movies I've seen in recent times that is a crowd pleaser.

Coda is a beautiful and heartwarming in every way and perfect.the acting by the family was magnificent Ruby deserves more Emilia Jones caught my attention.a beautiful story about Teenage girl in deaf family in a genre teenage girl in a deaf family This has been the strongest type of movie for quite a few years nowdealing with school, family, love etc. Of course 'CODA' has a twist with the deaf family aspect, and this helped it become one of the best films in 2021. I don't know how Oscars forget Emilia Jones for award is unacceptable . Overall this what i call "absolute cinema"Hitler's rating: 8.5/10.

reviews.review_title: Your feel good movie of the summer!
reviews.content: CODA (2021)Child of Deaf Adults. When I read this title, I thought I would be watching a sad movie similar to Sound of Metal; instead, it turned out to be a feel good film closer to Little Miss Sunshine. On the surface, it might seem like CODA is a coming of age story with the tropes that many of us have seen before. What makes it different though, is the entire deaf aspect and the nuanced way in which the narrative is crafted around it while offering opportunity for both sadness and good natured laughter. Yes laughter! The first half of the film is pure comedy and you wont believe how funny it is unless you see it.CODA is about a young girl Ruby and her deaf family. Being the only hearing person, she has spent her entire life as an interpreter for her mother, father and brother who make their livelihood through fishing. One day, Ruby signs up for choir and her teacher notices that she is highly talented and might have an opportunity to go to a prestigious college. It might seem like good news but in reality, they make Ruby feel torn between chasing a dream and fulfilling the immense responsibility for her family who rely on her for every little thing.If you are someone who is familiar with putting family first, you will find this story even more enjoyable. I did notice occasional cliches but I wasn't bothered by them because of how humane and pleasant the entire experience felt. Emilia Jones manages to brilliantly portray Ruby's struggle who can't imagine existing without her family and yet, can't stop dreaming of bigger things. There are plenty of moments to bring a smile to your face and quite a few that might bring a tear to your eye. I feel this touching story is perfect to watch on a summer day and I can't overemphasize how much I enjoyed it.P. S. Good luck forgetting the main song.Movies.shmovies on Instagram for movie and TV Shows.

reviews.review_title: Above average crowd pleaser, begins with truth but heads for conventionality
reviews.content: I'd give this one a 7.5 if IMDB would let me. It's the best movie I've seen from 2021 so far, but that's not saying much. For most of the film I thought I might be seeing a small classic. It's genuinely funny at times, and starts with unusual truthfulness for an American coming of age flick. But you could feel the creaky gears of conventionality starting up in the plot somehow; you know where it's headed, and the final scenes are closer to a made-for-video Disney flick than the genuine inspiration we got from the movie's first act.There is also a subplot about the protagonist's family's fishing business that didn't seem to be resolved. It was like the movie just forgot about that to focus on her.It's an above average crowd pleaser, and I'm not surprised to see it won an Academy Award. Emilia Jones is one to watch, and all the actors who play her hearing impaired family are fantastic too.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of 2021
reviews.content: CODA stars Emilia Jones, Troy Kostar, Marlee Martin, Eugenio Derbez and Daniel Durant in a coming of age film that follows a girl that is the only person in her family that isn't deaf, which causes some issues when she finds her passion for singing.This film is something I had never seen before. I've seen plenty of films that have deaf characters but I've never seen something that dives into that life the way this film did. We get to see all of the complications that come with being deaf and it really opens your eyes and makes you think about what it would be like.Emilia Jones plays the lead character Ruby Rossi and does an amazing job. You become extremely invested in this character fairly early on so throughout the entire film you are rooting for her and you feel the emotions she feels when dealing with her parents that can't really understand her passion for music.On the other side of this film we see her family who are trying as hard as they can to live a comfortable life. Troy Kostar is phenomenal in his role. His ability to act and display emotion without speaking is something I've never seen before. Daniel Durant and Marlee Martin are both amazing butt Troy is the stand out for me.This was also extremely funny in my opinion. There are moments that are fairly cheesy but overall they did a great job of making this film not only compelling and emotionally gripping but also entertaining.Overall CODA is an amazing film. It gives us a coming of age story that we've seen before but adds to it with the deep dive into the life of being the only hearing person in her family.9/10.
