CODA is a heart-warming and feel-good movie that will leave audiences both crying and laughing. It follows the story of Ruby, a deaf teenager who is the only hearing member of her family. While she loves them dearly, she feels like an outsider in her own home and longs for a life outside of their small town. When she falls in love with a hearing boy and starts to pursue her dreams of becoming a singer, she must decide between the life she wants and the family that she loves.CODA is an uplifting story about following your dreams and being true to yourself. It features amazing performances from its cast, particularly Emilia Jones as Ruby who spent nine months learning American Sign Language to play her role. The film is beautifully shot and captures the stunning landscapes of Cape Cod. It's an emotional and feel-good movie that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

reviews.review_title: It was a feel good movie but Best Picture??
reviews.content: This just didn't have the polish of typical Oscar winners. I suspected that if they only had 5 nominations like most years past, this wouldn't have even been nominated.Don't get me wrong, the scene from her deaf parents perspective at the concern was very sad for me as a musician, very moving for her dad to try to feel her sing at the end, but there were a handful of parts that felt more like "deleted scenes" you might see "bonus feature" but totally agree they weren't needed scenes. The acting just wasn't that great (beyond the parents), the whole shy singer turn star felt cliché, the student/teacher relationship was predictable, she happens to hit it off with her cute duet partner, etc.Power of the Dog wasn't my favorite either but it had that polish, suspense, tension, strong characters and acting that we have seen win Best Picture year after year. West Side Story had all those elements as well. This one had none of that. Maybe there was just a split of votes that happen to fall in Coda's favor? Do they need rank choice voting because I can't imagine Coda getting over half of the votes.I'm a big Apple TV+ as well. I'm a musician. I have empathy for the main character but still.

CODA which stands for Child Of Deaf Adult directed by Sian Heder is a movie about a girl named Ruby Rossi played by Emilia Jones who is a hearing girl in a deaf family who wants to pursue her passion of singing but when her family needs her to help in their fishing business, now Ruby has to struggle between choosing her passion of singing or help her family with their business. Most movies that have to do with high school life and a struggle are usually really bad movies and end up cheesy but this movie is just phenomenal and I can't stop thinking about this movie, some of my thoughts on the performances throughout the movie is Emilia Jones can play a tough, strong, and shy girl who is struggling to fit in because of her situation she is in being the only hearing person in her family who is deaf and she plays a person that can't fit in. The Scenes in CODA was nicely shot for example when Ruby was alone singing at the lake, the cinematography is pretty good. The chemistry between all the Characters have together is really amazing, The acting in the movie is just like if they were in real life as a family, or in a school. I was impressed during these scenes where Ruby and Miles played by Ferdia Walsh Peelo were singing in a duet for the first time ever Ruby keeps looking at Miles showing how much she is into him but Miles at this point isn't really into her and keeps looking at Bernardo played by Eugenio Derbez which I think this is a really good scene. Another scene I liked is when Ruby is trying to explain how she feels to sing to Bernardo but can't put it into words so she signs how she feels to sing to Bernardo, he can't understand what she is signing but he can understand that it makes her feel safe and comfortable. Also another scene I liked is When Ruby and Miles are singing at the concert Frank Rossi played by Trot Kotsur and Jackie Rossi played by Marlee Matlin are looking around to see the audiences reaction to their daughter singing at they see that people are enjoying their singing and some tearing up to their singing and at that moment they realize that their daughter has real talent, also Ruby explains to her Frank that the song that she was singing at the concert was about what it is to need another person which perfectly shows what the parents are in need of, they need Ruby. This Movie has little to no flaws and I really enjoyed CODA and I will give this movie a 10/10, the next time Sian Heder makes a movie if its anything like this I will surely watch it.

Takes the edge off a film that had plenty to like. Others here have said plenty about that, so let me focus now on that flaw.Remember, Ruby works on her father's boat and her presence is potentially vital, since she is the only one aboard who can hear. One day, she unilaterally decides - without telling anybody - to take the whole day off to go to a lake with the boy she fancies.It's a lovely day out and advances their relationship. But in her absence, her father and brother are unable to communicate with the observer placed on board their boat, do not hear radio broadcasts or hailer calls and end up being boarded by the suspicious coastguard. This set of circumstances incurs large fines the family cannot afford and, worse still, could put them permanently out of business!And yet, when she finally turns up, Ruby gets upset that the family is "trying to pin this on me". In other words, even when confronted with the dire consequences, she refuses to assume any guilt for the damage her terrible lack of responsiblity has caused.That is not so surprising among teenagers, but the film copmpounds the problem by letting her get away with it and instead pins the blame squarely on the parents for expecting too much of their daughter. It was a burden to carry, but she was an apparently mature young lady who had been doing a reasonable job since she was very young and the family had organized itself around that. So they depended on her and she let them down, very badly!Yes, kids should be encouraged to pursue their (realistic) dreams, but the universe does not stop for that to happen and life in a society entails all kinds of basic responsibilities that have to be fulfilled in order for that society to function. That is a far more important lesson to teach the younger generations!Another is the importance of communication. Ruby not only comes close to ruining the family business, but also nearly destroys her budding singing future by letting down her tutor, giving him the impression she's undisciplined and wasting his time, because she does not explain (just offers vague excuses) the difficulties she is having in reconciling all the commitments she has assumed.
Outstanding and overwhelming touching, simply it's one of the best.

reviews.review_title: Along with Sound of Metal, one of the best films with characters from the deaf community

The movie is great from start to finish, but what really got me the most is when everything went silent to imitate what a deaf person hears on a regular basis.This made me think after finishing the movie about how people with disabilities struggle in our society. Why didn't we get at least one sign language class in elementary or middle school to at least have the basic knowledge to communicate? I'm aware that there's no one sign language around the world but at least each country should introduce their sign language to the curriculum.All in all, the movie was great and I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: A film that works despite its familiarity
reviews.content: The Sundance Film Festival has always been known for giving a great platform to unassuming films by little-known filmmakers. Many of the festival's winners have gone on to win prestigious awards. CODA could be the next candidate in which this scenario occurs. Not only is it one of the biggest crowd-pleasers of the year, but the coming-of-age story gives the sneezy cast of deaf-mute performers a chance to shine.It is important to mention that CODA is based on the French comedy Do You Understand the Béliers. Whereas in the original work, however, only hearing actors embody the almost exclusively deaf-mute family members, here it is people with the actual affliction. At the latest since Sound of Metal showed this fascinating group in such a grandiose way, deaf-muteness in films has been on everyone's lips. Director Sian Heder wraps this concept in a film reminiscent of coming-of-age stories like Lady Bird and Juno. The youngest member of the family, Ruby, is the only hearing one in her family and helps her loved ones make ends meet as a translator in a less tolerant society. The family owns a fishing business, into which several obstacles get in the way as the plot unfolds. But that is not the main story. Rather, the film is told through Ruby's eyes and accompanies her as she is torn between staying true to her family or pursuing her dream as a singer. 19-year-old Emilia Jones plays this character as authentically and adolescently as possible, and you buy into her almost impossible situation, but one that seems so remote from our point of view. The best moments in CODA occur when she shares emotional dialogue with her parents and brother. Although they only gesture with sign language, you follow the conversation as if it were the spoken word we are used to. This is thanks to the great performances of Oscar winner Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur and Laniel Durant. They seem very bizarre and different at first, but it becomes increasingly clear that they too have normal concerns and needs apart from their deafness. Eugenio Derbez, as Ruby's mentor and singing teacher, is also a constant in the protagonist's life that we wish we had.Out the back, CODA lives up to all the hype as a crowd pleaser. Some scenes press hard on the tear gland and are carried by great sung musical accompaniment. Before that, however, the film takes almost half the time to finally get going. This is detrimental to the film because the plot lost me a little after the long delay. One should not expect surprises anyway. The film follows a classic pattern, but the predictability does it little harm. Rather, the fact that the family conflict built up in the first half never fully unfolds. Only between brother and sister is there a reckoning, but this is not really pursued. In retrospect, however, this is forgotten, as Heder knows how to rely on elements towards the end that simply appeal to filmgoers. I fell for that too and that is the reason why I enjoyed CODA so much in the end. Viewed as a whole, however, the film has obvious weaknesses, which is why I cannot rank it among the top tier coming-of-age stories.

reviews.review_title: Much deeper and nuanced than it first appears
reviews.content: Where do I begin? Few movies have moved me that way this movie has. I see a number of reviews using terms like "formulaic" or "by the numbers", which may have some basis, however, do not for a moment believe that is a full assessment of this beautifully told story.(I'm not hating on Hollywood, they are, after all, in it for the money not the art, and to that end they do a fine job. However, CODA is yet another stunning example of how the film industry outside of Hollywood produces wonderfully wonderful work! This movie is a wee gem!)CODA explores how people's interpretations of situations can be vastly different, and often not recognised by those sharing those situations, even loved ones.It lets us know that sometimes we need to stop being selfless and to do things for ourselves, for the benefit of our sanity, desires, dreams, and dare I say it... our souls! Simultaneously, the story tells us why we must stop being selfish, dependent, negative, turning can't do / won't do attitudes, beliefs, and actions around, giving new strength to the characters. It is a coming of age story, but not simply a teen coming of age, not by a long way.There is one scene that I just know will last with me forever. These powerful scenes come along very rarely in cinema, Tom Hanks' interpretation of the opera in Philadelphia is one. Liam Neeson in Schindler's List when he is counting the number of Jewish lives his Nazi pin could have bought is also one. Likewise, Jean Valjean's death scene / the finale of Les Misérables, is another example of a truly rare and exceptionally crafted moment (IMHO). CODA too, has one of these moments, and while I'd wager most would say it's the scene where Ruby sings to her father on the back of their pickup truck. For me, it's the duet scene, the scene we know is going to be pivotal, but then... That moment! Right there! Where everything changes, everyone becomes aware of more than themselves for a mere moment, and it's transformative in the most beautiful way, without a word being uttered, nor a sound being made!I will happily re-watch this movie, and joyfully re-experience those emotions again and again, I'm certain of this.To me this felt authentic, the acting was very much on point, (everyone is on point). It's clear Emelia Jones worked very hard to prepare for this role, highlighted by the fact that, at no moment ever does she look uncomfortable working on a fishing trawler, nor does she look like anything less than someone who has signed to communicate her entire life! She does, for the most part, look uncomfortable singing, but she's supposed to, and yet, It's apparent she has the singing chops to pull of the big singing moments.Look, do yourself a favour, if you haven't seen CODA yet then watch this movie! If you have seen it, then watch it again!Thank you for making CODA.

The Rossi family runs a fishing boat off the coast of Massachusetts and Ruby (Emilia Jones) is the only member of the clan who is not deaf. She joins the high school choir during her senior year and finds herself caught between, on the one hand, the demands of her (very close-knit) family, and on the other hand her aspirations to pursue voice in college.While this is a remake of a 2014 French movie, this reboot carves out its own identity by placing the material in the working class, fishing sub-culture of Gloucester, Massachusetts. That atmosphere added grit to the film, and the audience never doubts the genuineness of the setting. The parents (Marlee Matlin, Troy Katsur) have a wonderful chemistry and Ruby's brother (Daniel Durant) is also fantastic; and Emilia Jones absolutely shines as Ruby. We quickly learn that, despite the challenges presented by being deaf and the chaos caused by that, their family life is animated by love. I was touched by the honesty of their interactions and the beauty of their shared lives in spite of their common disability. This made Ruby's dilemma all the more poignant; how can she leave them given their dependence on her, but how can she not follow her own dreams?In our cynical day, this movie was uplifting--not by foisting a pre-conceived message on the audience--but by simply allowing the beauty of the Rossi's family life to radiate. The writing is intelligent and witty, and the dialogue, both spoken and signed, is heartfelt and often hilarious. The movie doesn't glorify the characters merely because they have a disability, nor are they prevented from acting out their full humanity--the highs and the lows--with integrity.This is a beautiful movie and worthy of the Best Picture award at the Oscars. Frankly, it caught me off guard that such a positive film--one not inundated with politically correct virtue signaling, took the top prize. This was heartening.

Sublime in so many ways, rarely has there been a story so genuine, so lovingly crafted, so expertly depicted. The Rossi family may be fictional, but couldn't be more real - a complex, lovingly dysfunctional, emotionally taxing quartet, seemingly mired in an inner-world missing one important sense - the ability to hear - except for the hearing daughter, Ruby - torn between her own yearnings and a lifelong sense of duty - to remain their bridge to a world of sound. It is exceedingly rare for a performance to master so many disparate nuances as that which Emilia Jones has accomplished. You will believe every fiber of her story...the signing, the singing - and likely not so silently cheer for her (and her family) to achieve a happily-ever-after outcome!

reviews.review_title: Not different from the average Disney Channel movie
reviews.content: Frankly, I'm disappointed that CODA won the Oscar for best movie, and I don't understand why the reviews and ratings are so high.Don't get me wrong, the goal of giving space to deaf people is noble, and it was about time that Hollywood started this process; nonetheless, this movie is nothing but sappy.The actors did a great job and their performances were by far the most enjoyable thing of the film, but the plot was really basic, and to me it wasn't different than the Disney Channel movies I used to watch when I was a kid. The obstacles that the protagonist has to face to achieve her dream are overcome very easily, and there is really no tension: from the very beginning, you just know there will be the happy ending with the girl going to music school, so the whole plot feels sort of fake.You can't even say that the concept is original, since it's basically a copy of a previous french movie.On a positive note, I think the dialogue between the protagonist and her dad is really moving, I admit I might have shed a tear in that moment.As an adult, I think I am too old for this kind of movie, but I would recommend showing it to kids or young adolescents.

reviews.review_title: Sian Heder comes up with a more intimate, touching, and satisfying version of this representative coming off age story
reviews.content: Nearly a decade after the release of "The Belier Family," Sian Heder comes up with a more intimate, touching, and satisfying version of this representative coming off age story.Although it contains its developmental problems, CODA presents a raw version of the problems faced by families in the deaf culture, and it follows the maturation of these relationships, showing how important it is to dream and be supported, regardless of our differences.The "no sound" scene during Rubie's presentation was the highlight of the film, in that it took me out of my regular train of thought, and made me analyze the film with another perspective. It felt so raw and real. I was a little emotional.Although the script is predictable, it is still well written and conveys the intended message. It's a very positivist film... Perhaps if the problems these families face had been deepened, as well as the consequences that follow, I would have felt a better approach. But I still recommend it to all families.

For me, that 1 minute was enough art, compassion, and social eye opening for an Academy Award.

reviews.review_title: Good acting, okay movie, implausible/inaccurate musically

One of the notes on the wall of the music room had a stem in the wrong direction (I haven't seen music in years but I'm not that out of the loop to know that it didn't look right). And she couldn't possibly learn enough about reading music to sight read for an audition. Also, did she really not think of signing to her parents during that first concert? reviews.review_title: Completely formulaic coming-of-age story that adds nothing to an already oversaturated library
reviews.content: Stop me if this sounds familiar: a high schooler from an outcast/quirky/underprivileged/working-class family discovers he/she has a passion for music/painting/theater/etc of some sort, and is guided by an off-kilter teacher with a mysterious/tragic/etc past who can seem cruel/weird at times but only wants what's best for the protagonist. However, the family does not support the protagonist because they need him/her to help their family business/does not believe the arts are a practical pursuit for financial independence/is anti-art. Ultimately the protagonist has to choose between his/her family or his/her passion, but whatever choice the protagonist makes, everything is reconciled at the end. Or not.Everyone and their mother has told this story. 90% of Japan's animated productions tell some variation of this story.Some try to add something new or subvert or satirize the genre in some way to stand out. Not CODA! CODA relies on its gimmick of using deaf actors to play deaf characters to emotionally manipulate the audience. Not dissimilar to how Boyhood was shot over decades.Don't get me wrong, it's great that deaf actors are getting representation, I just wish it wasn't just for a stupid gimmick.The film is passably made for what it is, but it does NOT deserve its accolades.TL;DR Skip this, and just rewatch Dead Poets Society instead.Or the Weird Al movie, which is a brilliant satire of the coming-of-age genre.
